If you are or have been a student and you want to continue your studies in Romania:

answers.answer: The CNRED (National Center for Diploma Recognition and Equivalence) helps Ukrainian citizens who have completed their studies abroad, obtain equivalence of their diplomas. It evaluates and recognizes study papers, and issues certificates or decisions of recognition of studies. This can assist Ukrainian citizens in enrolling in another cycle of studies in Romania, or accessing the Romanian labor market.

answers.answer: There are several options for Ukrainian children in Romania when it comes to their education. Firstly, there are online kindergartens (part-time kindergartens) which can be useful if you have a busy schedule but still want your child to receive an education. In addition, many Romanian schools offer courses taught by qualified teachers who speak both languages, making it easier for Ukrainian children to adapt to the new environment. Furthermore, there are numerous learning platforms available where students can study at home without having to attend traditional classrooms. Some private schools also provide free education to deserving students. Overall, these diverse educational opportunities ensure that Ukrainian children studying in Romania will not face any difficulty in accessing quality education.

answers.answer: The structure of the school year in Romania includes breaks for national and religious holidays. Some of the notable holidays include New Year's Day (1 January), Orthodox Christmas (7 January), Easter Monday, Labour Day (1 May), National Holiday (15 August), Independence Day (1 December), as well as some regional holidays such as Corpus Christi. Additionally, there may be local holidays specific to individual educational institutions if they have them. Please note that this information might not reflect the exact holiday dates for the 2024-2025 academic year, so it would be advisable to check with official sources for the most accurate information.
